title: Swampy is back: Activist who made his name in the 1990s returns to join Extinction Rebellion
text:
Swampy, the veteran eco-warrior who made his name during a series of environmental campaigns in the 1990s, has returned to activism saying that Extinction Rebellion gives him "hope".

Daniel Hooper, now 46, became a national figure after living underground for a week in a tunnel protesting against the rerouting of the A30 in Devon.

Hooper, who now lives in West Wales, was also involved in a series of high-profile environmental campaigns, also targeting the M11, Newbury bypass and Manchester Airport.

Now after more than a decade out of the headlines he has found himself back in court for being part of a group of ten Extinction Rebellion protesters who blocked the roads leading to one of the biggest oil refineries in Europe.

He told ITV News: "My beliefs are the same as they always were and I did have a quiet 10 years, almost to the point where you have apathy towards how we can change things, then Extinction Rebellion started happening.

Daniel Hooper aka Swampy outside Haverfordwest Magistrates Court Credit: Athena Pictures More

"You think there is hope and I believe there is hope and now everyone need to think about what we are doing, governments needs to change, companies need to change.

"We need People's Assemblies to decide what to do, this is a state of emergency."

Hooper had earlier been fined £40 and ordered to pay £85 costs and a £32 surcharge after appearing before magistrates in Haverfordwest.

He pleaded guilty to willful obstruction of a highway after handcuffing himself to a concrete block on the road to the Valero Pembroke Refinery during a protest last month.

Swampy during the height of his fame for activism Credit: Apex More

He told Magistrates: "I was doing it to prevent a greater crime, the eco crime of profit at the cost of the planet. I am pleading guilty, I can't really afford to keep coming to court."

Hooper, who at the height of his fame even appeared on Have I Got News For You, now lives in the village of Talley, Llandeilo, Carmarthenshire, known for its community of environmentalists who live in teepees.
description: Swampy, the veteran eco-warrior who made his name during a series of environmental campaigns in the 1990s, has returned to activism saying that Extinction Rebellion gives him "hope".
